Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Host specificity strategies in a binary mutualism:
Award.AbstractNarration:
All plants and animals, including humans have evolved to live in symbiotic association with microbes. At the cellular level, complex molecular circuitries monitor microbial populations and respond to either defend against harmful microbes, or recruit and maintain beneficial microbes. Current scientific knowledge is limited with regard to how animals distinguish among different microbes, enabling them to selectively recruit or restrict microbial colonization. This research focuses on understanding how bacterial symbionts interact with and affect their animal hosts, and how these interactions influence the evolution of inter-species cooperation. Three investigators with complementary expertise will conduct collaborative research on small soil-dwelling roundworms (nematodes) that have evolved mutually beneficial associations with a specific group of bacteria. Together the nematodes and bacteria form insecticidal complexes effective against a wide range of insect hosts, from which they derive nutrients for reproduction and dissemination. These associations involve different species of nematodes and bacteria, and current research indicates that different combinations have evolved varying degrees of dependence on each other. Research on these cooperative associations is poised to yield insights into the processes influencing selectivity and function of microbial symbioses. To help achieve this potential, this multidisciplinary research team will investigate for the first time specific bacterial traits contributing to host fitness in this system. Such knowledge will be critical to our understanding of the selective pressures influencing the evolution of specialized versus generalized associations between mutually benefiting partners.
High school, undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students at the three collaborating institutions will be trained in the areas of evolution, molecular biology, nematology, entomology, and bacteriology through direct scientific inquiry. Thus, this project will provide fundamental insights into the ubiquitous process by which animals recognize, maintain, and benefit from their beneficial microbial partners, and will help train future scientists with the expertise to further apply this knowledge

POR.DRECONTENT:
In nature, Steinernema nematodes carrying cognate Xenorhabdus symbionts in their intestine alternate between two environments: insect cadavers and soil. Within the insect, nematodes release the Xenorhabdus symbiont and undergo sexual reproduction, producing many thousands of offspring, which use the cadaver's metabolic resources. Once resources are exhausted, the nematodes develop into a non-feeding “dauer” form, known as the infective juvenile (IJ), which is colonized with their symbiotic partner. IJ progeny emerge from the insect cadaver, and persist in the soil until a new insect host can be infected. Steinernema nematodes benefit from the symbionts’ ability to suppress the insect immune response, kill the host and protect and degrade the insect cadaver. The bacteria in turn benefit from being carried by the IJ between the nutrient-rich resources of the insect host (Fig.1). The proposed research is based on our prior collaborative studies, which have revealed impacts of Xenorhabdus bacterial symbionts on three aspects of the nematode lifecycle (Fig. 1). Specifically, we discovered:

 

1)    Specificity in the ability of bacterial symbionts to support nematode reproduction (Murfin et al PNAS in review; McMullen et al. in preparation [Stage 1]

Through draft genome sequencing of nine bacterial symbiont strains and co-phylogenetic analysis, we demonstrate co-cladogensis between Steinernema feltiae nematode hosts and their corresponding Xenorhabdus bovienii symbionts, indicating likely coevolution. Laboratory crosses of the nematode hosts with native and non-native symbiont strains, revealed that combinations with the native bacterial symbiont and closely related strains performed significantly better than those with more divergent symbionts. These results suggest that strain-level diversity, or subspecies-level differences, in microbial symbionts can drive variation in the success of host-microbe associations. Furthermore, our results indicate that differential mutualism success can serve as positive reinforcement to maintain partner fidelity and ultimately shape large-scale phylogenetic patterns.

 

2) An environment-specific contribution of bacterial symbionts to IJ development (Sugar et al. 2012 [Stage 2])

Xenorhabdus bovienii exhibits phenotypic variation between orange-pigmented primary form and cream-pigmented secondary form. Each form can colonize IJ nematodes when cultured in vitro on agar. However, IJs did not develop or emerge from Galleria mellonella insects infected with that were soft and flexible, secondary-form infected insects retained a rigid exoskeleton structure. Xenorhabdus bovienii primary and secondary form isolates are virulent towards Manduca sexta and several other insects. However, primary form stocks present attenuated virulence, suggesting that X. bovienii, like Xenorhabdus nematophila may undergo virulence modulation.

 

3) A role of the nematode hosts in bacterial symbiont fitness (Bisch et al. in review [Stage3])

We showed that when disassociated from its nematode host (S. weiseri) the bacterium X bovienii CS03 strain is unable to grow and cause septicemia in  an insect host. We showed that Xb CS03 strain was very sensitive to cationic AMPs, which are produced in large amounts in the insect hemolymph by the fat body and participate in antimicrobial defense. We speculate that  during the natural infestation of an insect by the S. weiseri-Xb CS03 pair, the nematodes release their bacteria after this AMP secretion peak. S. weiseri nematode may also directly prevent AMP action in the insect host.
